text.p: Here are highlights of stories in Romania's press on Wednesday. Reuters has not verified these stories and does not vouch for their accuracy:
Business:
ROMANIA LIBERA
- Domestic power consumption rose 4.4 percent in 1996 from the previous year, the Renel RA electricity authority said.

- Under a new Finance Ministry decision, oil imports by the Romanian Oil Company (CRP) are no longer exempted from value added tax (VAT). CRP sources said the company did not even have the hard currency needed to pay for the imports.
- Agriculture Minister Dinu Gavrilescu said expected 1997 grain crop was 17 million tonnes. He also said milk output was expected to rise by 5.0 percent from the previous year.
ADEVARUL
- Prices of imported medicines are expected to rise by more than 15 percent.
- Deposits at the CEC commercial bank, formerly a savings bank, are on the rise and the bank plans to raise interest rates on deposits.
TINERETUL LIBER
- Economic Reform Minister Ulm Spineanu said the government would set forth its reform programme in less than two weeks.
LIBERTATEA
- The tourism ministry decided to liberalise hotel accommodation fees. Tourism operators welcome the step.
CRONICA ROMANA
- Romania's loan talks with the World Bank and the International Monetary Fund are expected to end in three weeks.
CURIERUL NATIONAL
- Bankcoop SA commercial bank jacked up interest rates on leu deposits starting January 20.
EVENIMENTUL ZILEI
- Furniture factories plan to increase prices by up to 15 percent.
General:
ADEVARUL
- Courts are expected to rule on Friday on request by union leader Miron Cosma's lawyer to have his client, detained over charges related to his role in 1991 miner riots, tried at liberty.
- A mining union leader says thousands of Jiu Valley coal miners would stage sit-in strikes in their pits unless their leader, Miron Cosma, is tried at liberty.
ROMANIA LIBERA

- Editorial asks whether the price of Romania's integration into NATO should be post-communist treaties with ex-Soviet neighbours that would implicitely sanction loss of Romanian lands to the Kremlin under the 1939 Nazi-Soviet pact.
EVENIMENTUL ZILEI
- Editorial says street protests in Albania should send a warning signal to Romania's ruling centrist coalition that "reformist programmes are no substitutes for bread."
LIBERTATEA
- Millions of Romanians will be affected by government's plans to liberalise bread, milk and meat prices, which newspaper says are expected to trigger big price hikes.
- Prices for rents go up as leu currency fell against the dolar. Rents for one room apartments in Bucharest went up to $100 per month.
JURNALUL NATIONAL
- Greater Romania Party (PRM) opposes "selling land to foreigners" as part of plans to amend post-communist laws.
- Romanian long-distance runner Iulia Negura says her food was laced with doping drugs while she trained near Bucharest.
COTIDIANUL
- Meat prices will go up starting February 1.
ZIUA
- French cinema star Gerard Depardieu is visiting Romania, as guest of a new local theatre company.
- Miners leaders gathered list of 30,000 signatures from Jiu Valley coalminers who say they took part in 1991 riots which ousted Romania's first post-communist government.
DIMINEATA

- "We started to reorganise the party and we want to turn it into an active and constructive opposition force," ex-President Ion Iliescu, leader of the Party of Social Democracy (PDSR) told press conference at party's headquarters. ($=5,360 lei)
-- Bucharest Newsroom, 40-1 3120264
